raw_comment:
What do you notice?
		I notice that without legacy status the more money your parents make the less of a chance that you will get admitted unless you are in the top 0.1%.  The trend does not completely carry over to legacy status students though.  Legacy status students acceptance rate generally increases the more their parents make and if you are in the top 0.1%, then your chances are about doubled.
What do you wonder?
	I wonder how long this trend will continue.  I also wonder which colleges they got these statistics from.  
How does this relate to you and your community?
	I am a high school junior, so I wonder how this will impact me and my peers when we apply to colleges.
Create a catchy headline that captures the graphâ€™s main idea.
	Parents make or break college admissions
ace_sentences: A student can have a legacy status or a non-legacy status.
If a student has a non-legacy status and the parents of the student make more money then the chance that the student gets admitted is lower.
If a student has a non-legacy status then the student has a high chance to get admitted only if the student is in the top 0.1%.
This trend does not completely apply to legacy-status students.
If a student has a legacy status and the parents of the student make more money then the acceptance rate of the student is higher.
If a student has a legacy status and the student is in the top 0.1% then the chance that the student gets admitted is about doubled.
I wonder how long this trend will continue.
I wonder which colleges provided these statistics.
I am a high school junior.
I have peers in my community.
I wonder how this trend will impact me when I apply to colleges.
I wonder how this trend will impact my peers when they apply to colleges.
The headline is: Parents make or break college admissions.
